TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF032098-ASIA - MULTI-SECTORAL TF FOR
            THE ENVIRONMENT,TF034933-INDONESIA - RAILWAY EFFICIENCY PROJECT,TF035237-INDONESIA - RAILWAY EFFICIENCY PROJECT,TF035318-INDONESIA - RAILWAY EFFICIENCY PROJCT,TF036832-INDONESIA - RAILWAY EFFICIENCY PROJECT,TF037262-INDONESIA - RAILWAY EFFICIENCY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Railway Efficiency
            Project for Indonesia was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was unsatisfactory. Lessons learned:
            The problem of commitment to reform was exacerbated by
            changes in the senior management who was advocating the
            reforms. Some resistance arose from the outset from
            Directorate General of Land Communication (DGLC) and even
            the Daops in Perumka/PTKA, and the commitment of Ministry of
            Finance was not as strongly demonstrated as that of Bappenas
            and the railways. The studies undertaken have increased the
            awareness of Railway Persero (PTKA's) board and staff,
            the IACC and senior government officials of the main issues
            involved in restructuring, as well as the different
            alternatives and approaches, and critical prerequisites for
            any successful reform. Reform processes are inherently
            complex to implement, require high degree of stakeholder
            consultation, analysis of impacts on the various affected
            groups and consensus building. Simplified and harmonized
            procurement procedures are necessary.
